bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 1, 1942

div1.p: Hench informs Kean that he has received 22 fever charts from Jessie Ames. He requests clarification in regards to remarks on the back of Dean's fever chart.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 1, 1942
div1.opener:
Recd Aug 5/42
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 1, 1942
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
Gen. Jefferson R. Kean
2804 N Street N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Although I am leaving for my first assignment this next Thursday,
I have taken a little time for my yellow fever hobby. The biblical instruction,
“Seek and you shall find,” has certainly proven true in my case. As you know,
long search on my part failed to uncover the original fever charts on the
experimental yellow fever cases in the Surgeon General's office, the National
Archives, and elsewhere. Recently I saw a letter from Doctor Ames to the Surgeon
General written in 1905, requesting that the charts be sent him for study as he
had planned to write a book. There was no record of this letter in the files in
Washington. Acting on this hunch, I wrote Mrs. Ames and lo and behold she had
a large envelope with twenty-two original fever charts therein. Among them were
those of Carroll, Lazear, Dean, Moran, Kissinger, etc., also your own fever chart
and one of Doctor Ames himself. Mrs. Ames graciously (on my none too subtle
request) contributed these fever charts to our yellow fever museum. I had photo-
stats made of them for her and herewith send you a photostat of your own fever
chart and four sheets of clinical notes about you. Please note how neatly the
fever charts are made out. That is true of practically all of them. The neatness
of these fever charts had made me suspect that they were not really the “originals”
but were copied during the patient's recovery and convalescence, either from the
original fever charts which having been made out from day to day may have appeared
rather sloppy or perhaps from merely clinical notes like those of yours which
I enclose. I assume that these notes about you are in Lambert's handwriting. Is
this true? Do you think that he made out a fever graph from day to day which
original was destroyed, or has not yet been recovered, or do you think Ames'
comment on the envelope that these are the original charts is correct?

I enclose the photostatic copy of the outside of the large manila
envelope containing all these charts. The first and last paragraphs are in
Doctor Ames' handwriting. The paragraph in the middle was written later by
Mrs. Ames. Please note Doctor Ames' comments on the back of Dean's fever graph.
His expression, “the manner of taking poison,” intrigues me greatly. At first
I wondered if here wasn't another human interest story but never having heard any
hints that Dean tried to take poison I have decided Ames was talking about the
poison of yellow fever and that he meant the manner of his receiving the yellow
fever inoculation. Is this your interpretation? Please keep all these charts
for yourself except Ames' note about Dean. I would appreciate it if you would
return this with your comment and interpretation written on the back.

The men in the Surgeon General's office, General Hillman, Colonel
Lull and Major Durward Hall have been extremely kind to me. In all things so far
they have kept their promises to me. I was delighted to hear from Major Hall
this week that they consider the unit which I worked up an unusually good one.
Major Hall's letter says, “I believe that you should know that in all our
experience in processing such cases for specific unit duty at specific stations,
I have not come across a group so well worked up and projected as your proposed
group.” Maybe this praise is a little too fulsome, but none the less it is
encouraging. I could have sent them twice the number of excellent applications
that I sent. Already our group are being assigned to Camp Carson Station Hospital,
Colorado Springs and a few are enroute there now. I leave this Thursday night,
August 6, for some preliminary training at the Station Hospital, Fort Custer,
Michigan. I understand that Lt. Col. Richman is the commanding officer of the
Station Hospital at Fort Custer and Col. Clyde Oatman is the chief surgeon at
Fort Custer, also that Col. Floyd Hunter is the chief surgeon at Camp Carson.
Do you happen to know any of these men?

Permit me to drop you a note from time to time and please give
Mrs. Kean our kindest regards.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, Philip S Hench
P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:as
Dr Ames's indorsement on the Dean chart
was returned to Dr Hench's office at the
Mayo Clinic on Aug 7. 1942. I answered
